question_details.query: What evidence exists for the effectiveness of different strategies to combat white-nose syndrome in bats?

summary_details.relevant_summary: Two randomized, controlled studies evaluated treating little brown bats with a probiotic bacterium: in Canada, treatment at the time of white-nose syndrome infection increased survival and reduced disease symptoms in caged bats, whereas treatment 21 days prior did not increase survival and was associated with worse symptoms; in the USA, treatment increased survival for free-flying bats within a mine but did not increase survival for caged bats and resulted in similar disease severity to untreated bats (2008). No studies were found that evaluated vaccinating bats against the white-nose syndrome pathogen (1011), decontaminating clothing and equipment after entering caves (2006), restricting human access to bat caves (1010), or breeding bats in captivity to supplement wild populations affected by white-nose syndrome (2009).

question_details.query: How do different methods for restricting public access to bat hibernation sites, such as gates versus fences, compare in their effects on bat populations?

summary_details.relevant_summary: Across studies, installing cave gates showed mixed effects on bat populations: three of four before-and-after studies reported more or similar numbers of bats after gating while one reported fewer, and a replicated before-and-after study found population increases or slower declines for 13 of 20 Indiana bat colonies; a replicated site comparison found no difference in growth rates between gated and ungated caves, and one study found bats in a gated cave lost more body mass than bats in an unmodified cave [999]. Gate design influenced behavior: bats circled more and entered less after gating in one study; funnel designs were used more than round bar or angle iron designs; reducing bar spacing reduced passes; and significantly fewer bats emerged from a gated cave compared to a fenced cave in a paired comparison [999]. For fencing, evidence was limited but indicated no difference in population growth rates or occupancy between fenced/gated and unfenced caves in a replicated site comparison, and replacing a steel gate with a fence led to significantly more emerging southeastern myotis and gray myotis bats [1991]. Overall, studies directly comparing structures reported reduced emergence with gates relative to fences, while broader comparisons showed neutral to positive abundance responses with well-designed gates and neutral population metrics with fencing [999, 1991].
